Legal_Issue: Whether Koo met the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Koo was physically present in Canada for only 232 days out of the required 1095 days within four years preceding the application; maintained business interests in Hong Kong and did not establish Canada as his primary residence
Court_Ruling: Koo failed to meet the residency requirement; appeal dismissed
Defendant_Behavior: Frequent visits to Canada without establishing primary residence
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient physical presence in Canada to meet statutory residency requirement
Legal_Standard: Three years (1095 days) of accumulated residence in Canada within four years before application
Assessment_Factor: Duration and continuity of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a decision of a Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, travel history, evidence of ties to Hong Kong and Canada
Application_Basis: Accumulated residency calculation over four-year period
Evidence_Assessed: Koo's travel records and residential ties
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Citizenship Judge’s decision and grant of citizenship
Governing_Rule: To qualify for citizenship, applicant must have been physically resident in Canada for at least 1095 days within the four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation or proof demonstrating continuous or substantial residence in Canada
Outcome: Denial of citizenship due to failure to meet residency requirement
Harm_Assessment: No harm to public interest; integrity of citizenship process upheld
Cause_Description: Koo's denial of citizenship due to insufficient residency
Evidence_Handling: Travel records and residency patterns reviewed to assess compliance with s. 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Issues: Absence of evidence showing establishment of primary residence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – only 232 days of physical presence
Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed objective evidence of physical presence and residential intent
Decision_Rationale: Statutory residency requirement is strictly applied; frequent visits do not substitute for actual residence
Evidentiary_Issues: Limited evidence of Canadian residential ties compared to strong ties to Hong Kong
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective test of physical presence and residence under s. 5(1)(c)
